resource.name: Financial Health Dashboard
resource.description:
Open Michigan (OpenMichigan@michigan.gov) is the official State of Michigan account.  Any items created by other user accounts are not endorsed by the State of Michigan. 

Standard financial reports are highly technical and complex, making it difficult to determine the real condition of government's financial health. The information provided in this dashboard provides measurements that are easy to understand, providing a clear picture of the financial health of government in Michigan. With measurements ranging from how government is doing in addressing pension obligations to information on total revenue and expenditures, this dashboard provides key metrics for financial health.

columns_description: What this means: Governments do not always have cash on hand to pay for large projects, like new roads or buildings, or even to make scheduled payments. Like households, governments borrow to pay for larger expenditures or to address cash flow problems. Source: Michigan CAFR, U.S. Census, Michigan Dept. of Education Note: Information for Local Governments only available through 2011.

Why it Matters: Adequate funding for pension and other postemployment benefits (retiree health, dental, vision, and life insurance benefits) assures employees and retirees that their pension and other postemployment benefits will be available and provides evidence that state government is fiscally sound. The following chart shows the funding gap between pension and other postemployment benefit obligations and assets set aside for those benefits.
Source: Michigan CAFR, Annual Financial Statements for MSERS, MPSERS, MERS, DGRS and DPFRS & State Budget Office Analysis
Note: This change begins with 2006, the first year accounting standards required separate disclosure of OPEB.

Why it Matters: At the end of fiscal year 2011, the state and local government workforce (including school district employees) consisted of 429,280 employees. Source: U.S. Census, Michigan Civil Service Workforce Report & SBO Analysis

Why it Matters:  As of 2013, the school district workforce consisted of 256,485 employees. Since 2006, the number of school district employees has decreased by 5.11%. 
Source: Center for Educational Performance and Information

Why it Matters:  As of September 30, 2013, the classified state government workforce consisted of 47,739 employees. This represents a decrease of 20% since fiscal year 2002, when there were over 60,000 state employees. 
Source: Michigan Civil Service Workforce Report

Like households, governments borrow to pay for larger expenditures or to address cash flow problems. Source: Michigan CAFR, U.S. Census, Michigan Dept. of Education Note: Information for Local Governments only available through 2011.

Why it Matters: For fiscal year 2011, local government revenues totaled $29.0 billion. The following chart shows government revenues by category. 
Source:  U.S. Census & SBO Analysis
https://www.census.gov/govs/state/

Why it Matters: Funding gaps occur when ongoing expenditures are greater than ongoing revenues, creating an unstable financial environment. Structural balance, where ongoing revenues adequately support ongoing expenditures, ensures citizens and businesses that the government's fiscal house is in order. Prior to fiscal year 2011, state government spending levels often exceeded total revenues. For fiscal year 2013, revenues exceeded spending by $2.5 billion. Source: Michigan CAFR

Why it Matters: In fiscal year 2013, state government revenues totaled $52.8 billion. Taxes made up approximately 49% of state government revenues, while grants, primarily from the federal government, comprised 33%. Revenues in the chart below are greater than revenue available for expenditures because of the inclusion of certain taxes and other revenues that were earned but not collected until future years. Source: Michigan CAFR

Why it Matters: For fiscal year 2013, state government expenditures totaled $50.3 billion. Community health, hospitals and human services (including cash assistance, disability insurance and food stamps) accounted for 39% of state government expenditures. K-12 and higher education expenditures comprised 29%. Expenditures in the chart below are greater than annually budgeted expenditures because of long-term obligations such as pension, post-employment benefits and long-term debt being included in the calculation. 
Source: Michigan CAFR

Why it Matters:  It is considered good practice to keep at least 10% of annual operating expenditures in "savings". This allows the government to cover unexpected expenses or drops in revenue. The following chart shows the reserves maintained by state government. 
Source: Michigan CAFR

Why it Matters:  Positive cash balances help state government minimize borrowing costs and meet current obligations. For several years, state government has not maintained sufficient cash balances in its major funds (the General Fund and School Aid Fund) in order to make scheduled payments. As a result, in eight of the last ten years, the state has borrowed approximately $1 billion at the beginning of each fiscal year that is paid back with interest prior to the end of the fiscal year. The cash position improved in fiscal year 2012 to the point that such short-term borrowing was not necessary in fiscal years 2012 or 2013 and the major funds ended fiscal year 2013 with cash balances totaling $2.1 billion. 
Source: Michigan Dept. of Treasury Annual Reports

Why it Matters: Revenue dedicated debt has specific revenue streams that are dedicated to paying the annual debt service. This chart shows that the ratio of dedicated revenues to the annual debt service amount has generally declined over the past ten years, but remains sufficient to cover the debt service. Source: Michigan CAFR

Why it Matters:  Adequate funding for pension and other postemployment benefits (retiree health, dental, vision, and life insurance benefits) assures state employees and retirees that their pension and other postemployment benefits will be available and provides evidence that state government is fiscally sound. The following chart shows the funding gap between pension and other postemployment benefit obligations and assets set aside for those benefits. 
Source: Michigan State Employees Retirement System, Michigan CAFR

Source:  U.S. Census & Michigan Dept. of Education https://www.census.gov/govs/state/

Why it Matters: Funding gaps occur when ongoing expenditures are greater than ongoing revenues, creating an unstable financial environment. Structural balance, where ongoing revenues adequately support ongoing expenditures, ensures citizens and businesses that the government's fiscal house is in order.   

 Prior to fiscal year 2011, state government spending levels often exceeded total revenues. For fiscal year 2013, revenues exceeded spending by $2.5 billion. 
Source: Michigan CAFR

Why it Matters:  In fiscal year 2013, state government revenues totaled $52.8 billion. Taxes made up approximately 49% of state government revenues, while grants, primarily from the federal government, comprised 33%. Revenues in the chart below are greater than revenue available for expenditures because of the inclusion of certain taxes and other revenues that were earned but not collected until future years.
Source: Michigan CAFR

Why it Matters: For fiscal year 2013, state government expenditures totaled $50.3 billion. Community health, hospitals and human services (including cash assistance, disability insurance and food stamps) accounted for 39% of state government expenditures. K-12 and higher education expenditures comprised 29%. Expenditures in the chart below are greater than annually budgeted expenditures because of long-term obligations such as pension, post-employment benefits and long-term debt being included in the calculation. Source: Michigan CAFR

Why it Matters:  The annual budget is the spending plan for government. The budget is built on expected revenue collections from citizens and businesses, the federal government, and other local entities. The budget seeks to strike a balance between the revenues collected and spending incurred by government to serve its citizens. 
Source: Michigan Senate Fiscal Agency - Appropriation History

Why it Matters:  Having a healthy balance of savings in the Rainy Day Fund is not only fiscally responsible, it provides citizens and businesses with confidence that the state has planned for unseen changes. The state's Rainy Day Fund (also known as the Budget Stabilization Fund) is designed to help the state weather challenging economic periods or unforeseen emergencies. The Rainy Day Fund peaked at $1.3 billion in fiscal year 2000, but was quickly depleted. Michigan began rebuilding the fund balance in fiscal year 2012 and projects that the balance will be almost $500 million at the end of fiscal year 2015. The upward progression of the fund balance was impacted in fiscal year 2014 by the withdrawal of $194.8 million to support the Detroit bankruptcy settlement, providing added resources for the recovery of Michigan's largest city. That withdrawal will be repaid to the state's Rainy Day Fund in the amount of $17.5 million annually from tobacco settlement funds. 
Source:  Michigan CAFR

Why it Matters:  Like households, governments borrow to pay for large expenditures or to address cash flow problems. Reducing state government debt ensures financial stability, takes the burden of debt off of future generations and helps fuel economic recovery and job creation. 

 When it borrows, state government issues general obligation bonds, which are backed by the full faith and credit of state government, or revenue bonds, which are backed by designated revenue streams. Independent authorities, such as the Michigan Finance Authority, also issue revenue bonds. 
Source: Michigan CAFR

Why it Matters: Like households, governments borrow to pay for large expenditures or to address cash flow problems. Reducing state government debt ensures financial stability, takes the burden of debt off of future generations and helps fuel economic recovery and job creation. When it borrows, state government issues general obligation bonds, which are backed by the full faith and credit of state government, or revenue bonds, which are backed by designated revenue streams. Independent authorities, such as the Michigan Finance Authority, also issue revenue bonds. Source: Michigan CAFR

 When it borrows, state government issues general obligation bonds, which are backed by the full faith and credit of state government, or revenue bonds, which are backed by designated revenue streams. Independent authorities, such as the Michigan Finance Authority, also issue revenue bonds. 
Source: Michigan CAFR

Why it Matters: Debt per capita represents the portion of total state government debt that is "owed" by each Michigan citizen. From 2003 to 2009, debt per capita increased each year, from $1,176 in 2003 to $2,420 in 2009. Debt per capita decreased slightly in 2010 and 2011 before increasing again in 2012 to $2,646. The primary reason for the 2012 increase was the issuance of bonds in order to repay federal advances received in prior years by the Michigan Unemployment Trust Fund, thereby eliminating the deficit in that fund. The debt per capita decreased slightly in 2013. 
Source:  Michigan CAFR

Why it Matters:  Revenue dedicated debt has specific revenue streams that are dedicated to paying the annual debt service. Source: Michigan CAFR

Why it Matters: Adequate funding for pension and other postemployment benefits (retiree health, dental, vision, and life insurance benefits) assures state employees and retirees that their pension and other postemployment benefits will be available and provides evidence that state government is fiscally sound. The following chart shows the funding gap between pension and other postemployment benefit obligations and assets set aside for those benefits. Source: Michigan State Employees Retirement System, Michigan CAFR

Why it Matters:  Unemployment benefits are funded by employer taxes and federal dollars. When unemployment compensation fund balances are insufficient to fund current benefits, the fund borrows from the federal government. As shown in the chart below, the unemployment compensation fund balance had declined from a surplus of $1.1 billion in fiscal year 2004 to a deficit of $2.8 billion at the end of fiscal year 2011, as a result of unemployment benefits paid to individuals continuing to exceed unemployment contributions collected from employers. In fiscal year 2012, the fund received the proceeds of a bond issuance, which were used to repay outstanding advances from the federal government. The fund ended fiscal year 2013 with a positive fund balance of $1.8 billion. 
Source: Michigan CAFR

 For fiscal year 2011, local government revenues exceeded local government spending by $1.7 billion. 
Source:  U.S. Census & SBO Analysis https://www.census.gov/govs/state/

Why it Matters: For fiscal year 2013, school district expenditures totaled $20.1 billion. Instruction and instructional support accounted for 56.99% of school district expenditures. Source: Michigan Department of Education http://www.michigan.gov/mde/0,4615,7-140--21539--,00.html

Why it Matters:  It is considered good practice to keep at least 10% of annual operating expenditures in "savings". This allows school districts to cover unexpected expenses or drops in revenue. The following chart shows the reserves maintained by school districts. 
Source: Michigan Department of Education
Note: The reserves are expressed as a percentage of unrestricted net assets available for spending in governmental funds relative to total expenditures in the governmental funds.

Why it Matters:  Healthy cash balances help schools minimize borrowing costs and meet current obligations. The following chart shows the cash balances maintained by school districts. 
Source: Michigan Dept. of Education

Why it Matters:  Adequate funding for pension and other postemployment benefits (retiree health, dental, vision, and life insurance benefits) assures school district employees and retirees that their pension and other postemployment benefits will be available and provides evidence that school districts are fiscally sound. The following chart shows the funding gap between pension and other postemployment benefit obligations and assets set aside for those benefits.

http://www.michigan.gov/orsschools/0,1607,7-206-36585---,00.html
Note: This chart begins with 2006, the first year accounting standards required separate disclosure of OPEB.

Why it Matters:  In 2002, Michigan had 1.7 million students enrolled in K-12 schools. Because of out-migration and the aging of Michigan's population, the number of K-12 students has since declined by 11.18%. 
Source:  Michigan CAFR, Michigan Department of Education
http://www.michigan.gov/budget/0,1607,7-157-13406_13419---,00.html
